Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story: Every day at 4:30 p.m., I’m supposed to light the lamp and offer prayers at my home altar. It’s a ritual I’ve followed since childhood, a quiet moment to connect with the divine and honor my Hindu faith. But as a telemarketer, my life is ruled by the clock and the relentless ping of the compliance system. My breaks are scheduled to the minute, and any unscheduled downtime is flagged. Today, my break is set for 5:00 p.m., but I can already feel the anxiety building as the clock nears 4:30. My heart pounds as I imagine the lamp sitting unlit, the prayers unsaid, while I’m tethered to my headset, reciting the same sales pitch. I know my family expects me to keep up the tradition, and I expect it of myself too. But the thought of risking a warning—or worse, my job—by stepping away from my desk even for five minutes fills me with dread. I stare at the clock, torn between the demands of my faith and the rigid rules of my workplace, feeling the weight of both pressing down on me.
